clinical_study.brief_title: Impact of Antibiotic Prophylaxis in Per-oral Endoscopic Myotomy for Esophageal Motor Disorders
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Antibiotic Prophylaxis and Conditioning Modalities in Per Oral Endoscopic Myotomy for Esophageal Motor Disorders

brief_summary.textblock:
No recommendation regarding antibiotic prophylaxis and preparation modalities are available for patients with esophageal motor disorders who benefit from Per-Oral Endoscopic Myotomy (POEM). The aim of our study was to evaluate the impact of antibiotic prophylaxis on the POEM's safety.
This study was a comparative and multicentric retrospective analysis of a database prospectively maintained. Patients over 18 year's old with esophageal motor disorders confirmed by prior manometry, who underwent POEM were included. The primary endpoint was the occurrence of complications, as classified by Cotton, based on whether or not antibiotic prophylaxis was administered.

primary_outcome.measure: The occurence of postoperative complications, according to Cotton's classification
primary_outcome.description: Depending on whether or not antibiotic prophylaxis was administered

secondary_outcome.measure: The evaluation of the efficacy of the procedure
The occurence of perioperative and postoperative complications
The C-Reactive Protein and white blood cells count sampled
secondary_outcome.description: Blood test the day after the procedure, level of CRP in mg/L

arm_group.description: Cefazolin: 2g or Amoxicillin - clavulanic acid: 1g x 3 during 7 days

study_pop.textblock: Adults patients presenting a major esophageal motor disorder confirmed by prior manometry according to the Chicago classification and treated by per-oral endoscopic myotomy after a multidisciplinary meeting decision. Under-age patients were excluded.

criteria.textblock:
